Problem Statement: A double-slit interference is produced by plane parallel light of wavelength $\lambda$ passing through two slits of unequal widths, say $w_{1}=20 \lambda$ and $w_{\Omega}=40 \lambda$, their centers being $1000 \lambda$ apart. If the observation is made on a screen very far away from the slits, i.e., at a distance $L \gg 1000 \lambda$, determine the separation $\delta x$ between adjacent maxima.
Solution:
As $w_{2}=2 w_{1}, L>w_{1}, w_{2}$, we may take the amplitudes of the electric field vectors produced by the slits $S_{1}$ and $S_{2}$ individually on the screen to be $E$ and $2 E$ respectively. Since $I \propto E^{2}$, the corresponding intensities are $I_{1}=I_{0}$, say, $I_{2}=4 I_{0}$. For double-slit interference the resultant amplitude is given by the vector sum of $E_{1}$ and $E_{2}$ making an angle $\delta$ equal to the phase difference. Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
I &=I_{1}+I_{2}+2 \sqrt{I_{1} I_{2}} \cos \delta \\
&=I_{0}+4 I_{0}+4 I_{0} \cos (2 \pi d \sin \theta / \lambda)=5 I_{0}+4 I_{0} \cos (2000 \pi \sin \theta),
\end{aligned}
$$

where $d$ is the separation of the centres of the slits, being equal to $1000 \lambda$, $\sin \theta \approx \frac{x}{L}, x$ being the distance on the screen from the centre of the interference pattern. As $L>x, \sin \theta \simeq \theta$ and adjacent maxima occur when $2000 \pi \delta \theta=2 \pi$, or $\delta \theta=\frac{1}{1000}$, giving

$$
\delta x=L \delta \theta=\frac{L}{1000} .
$$

Problem Statement: A double-slit interference is produced by plane parallel light of wavelength $\lambda$ passing through two slits of unequal widths, say $w_{1}=20 \lambda$ and $w_{\Omega}=40 \lambda$, their centers being $1000 \lambda$ apart. If the observation is made on a screen very far away from the slits, i.e., at a distance $L \gg 1000 \lambda$, determine an analytic expression for the intensity on the screen as a function of $x$ when $x=0$ is at the exact center of the pattern.
Solution:
As $w_{2}=2 w_{1}, L>w_{1}, w_{2}$, we may take the amplitudes of the electric field vectors produced by the slits $S_{1}$ and $S_{2}$ individually on the screen to be $E$ and $2 E$ respectively. Since $I \propto E^{2}$, the corresponding intensities are $I_{1}=I_{0}$, say, $I_{2}=4 I_{0}$. For double-slit interference the resultant amplitude is given by the vector sum of $E_{1}$ and $E_{2}$ making an angle $\delta$ equal to the phase difference. Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
I &=I_{1}+I_{2}+2 \sqrt{I_{1} I_{2}} \cos \delta \\
&=I_{0}+4 I_{0}+4 I_{0} \cos (2 \pi d \sin \theta / \lambda)=5 I_{0}+4 I_{0} \cos (2000 \pi \sin \theta),
\end{aligned}
$$

where $d$ is the separation of the centres of the slits, being equal to $1000 \lambda$, $\sin \theta \approx \frac{x}{L}, x$ being the distance on the screen from the centre of the interference pattern. As $L>x, \sin \theta \simeq \theta$ and adjacent maxima occur when $2000 \pi \delta \theta=2 \pi$, or $\delta \theta=\frac{1}{1000}$, giving

$$
\delta x=L \delta \theta=\frac{L}{1000} .
$$The diffraction intensity distribution due to a slit of width $w$ is given by $\sim\left(\frac{\sin \beta}{\beta}\right)^{2}$, where $\beta=\frac{\pi w}{\lambda} \sin \theta$. Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
&I_{1}=I_{0}\left(\sin \beta_{1} / \beta_{1}\right)^{2}, \quad \text { where } \beta_{1}=\pi w_{1} \sin \theta / \lambda=20 \pi \sin \theta, \\
&I_{2}=4 I_{0}\left(\sin \beta_{2} / \beta_{2}\right)^{2}, \quad \text { where } \beta_{2}=\pi w_{2} \sin \theta / \lambda=40 \pi \sin \theta .
\end{aligned}
$$

The first zeros occur at angular distances from the centre of $\theta_{1}$ and $\theta_{2}$ given by

$$
20 \pi \sin \theta_{1} \simeq 20 \pi \theta_{1}=\pi \text {, or } \theta_{1}=\frac{1}{20} \text {, and } \theta_{2}=\frac{1}{40} \text {. }
$$

Hence the angular widths of the central maxima are

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta \theta_{1}=2 \theta_{1} &=\frac{1}{10}, \\
\Delta \theta_{2} &=\frac{1}{20} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The corresponding widths are then

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\Delta x_{1}=L \theta_{1}=L / 10, \\
&\Delta x_{2}=L \theta_{2}=L / 20 .
\end{aligned}
$$The width of the overlap of these central maxima is $L / 20$, and the number of fringes is $(\mathrm{L} / 20) /(\mathrm{L} / 1000)=50$.The intensity maximum and minimum in the center of the pattern are given by $\cos \delta=1$ and $\cos \delta=-1$ respectively. Hence we have the ratio

$$
\frac{I_{\max }}{I_{\min }}=\frac{9 I_{0}}{I_{0}}=9 .
$$Taking diffraction effect into account gives the fields produced by $S_{1}$ and $S_{2}$ respectively as

$$
\begin{aligned}
&E_{1}=E_{0}\left(\sin \beta_{1} / \beta_{1}\right), \\
&E_{2}=2 E_{0}\left(\sin \beta_{2} / \beta_{2}\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

where $E_{0}$ is a constant.

With $\beta_{2}=2 \beta_{1}$, we have

$$
E=\left|\mathbb{E}_{1}+\mathbb{E}_{2}\right|=E_{0} \frac{\sin \beta_{1}}{\beta_{1}}(5+4 \cos \delta)^{\frac{1}{2}}
$$

The intensity is therefore

$$
I(x)=I_{0}\left(\frac{\sin \frac{20 \pi x}{L}}{\frac{20 \pi x}{L}}\right)^{2}\left(5+4 \cos \frac{2000 \pi x}{L}\right)
$$

Problem Statement:
A point source $S$ located at the origin of a coordinate system emits a spherical sinusoidal wave in which the electric field $E_{1}$ is given by $E_{1}=$ $A\left(\frac{D}{r}\right) \cos \left(\omega t-\frac{2 \pi r}{\lambda}\right)$, where $r$ is the distance from $S$. In addition, there is a plane wave propagating along the $x$-axis. This wave is given by

$$
E_{2}=A \cos \left(\omega t-\frac{2 \pi x}{\lambda}\right) .
$$

(Note that we treat both $E_{1}$ and $E_{2}$ as scalar waves in this problem.) Both waves are incident on a flat screen perpendicular to the $x$-axis and at a distance $D$ from the origin, as shown in the figure. Compute the resultant intensity $I$ at the screen as a function of the distance $y$ from the $x$-axis for values of $y$ small compared with $D$. Express $I$ in terms of $y, D, \lambda$ and the intensity $I_{0}$ at $y=0$.
Solution:
The electric field $E$ at a point, distance $r$ from the origin, on the screen is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
E &=E_{1}+E_{2}=A\left[\frac{D}{r} \cos \left(\omega t-\frac{2 \pi r}{\lambda}\right)+\cos \left(\omega t-\frac{2 \pi x}{\lambda}\right)\right] \\
& \approx A\left[\cos \left(\omega t-\frac{2 \pi r}{\lambda}\right)+\cos \left(\omega t-\frac{2 \pi x}{\lambda}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

where we have used the approximation $r \approx D$.

For $y<D$, we have

$$
r=\left(D^{2}+y^{2}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}} \approx D\left(1+\frac{y^{2}}{2 D^{2}}\right)
$$

and thus

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
E &=A\left[\cos \left(\omega t-\frac{2 \pi D\left(1+\frac{y^{2}}{2 D^{2}}\right)}{\lambda}\right)+\cos \left(\omega t-\frac{2 \pi D}{\lambda}\right)\right] \\
&=2 A \cos \frac{\pi y^{2}}{D \lambda} \cdot \cos \left(\omega t-\frac{2 \pi D\left(1+\frac{y^{2}}{4 D^{2}}\right)}{\lambda}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
I \propto E^{2} \propto \cos ^{2} \frac{\pi y^{2}}{D \lambda} .
$$

Let $I=I_{0}$ at $y=0$; we then have

$$
I=I_{0} \cos ^{2}\left(\frac{\pi y^{2}}{D \lambda}\right) .
$$

As the distance from the centre increases, the fringes become closer. This is similar to Fresnel's zone plate.

Problem Statement:
A plane wave of wavelength $\lambda$ is incident on a system having 3 slits of width a separated by distances $d$. The middle slit is covered by a filter which introduces a $180^{\circ}$ phase change.

Calculate the angle $\theta$ for the first interference minimum.
Solution:
By the Huygens-Fresnel principle, the amplitude at a point on the screen is given by (for Fraunhofer diffraction)

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi=& \frac{A_{0}}{a} e^{-i w t}\left[\int_{0}^{a} e^{i 2 \rho x} d x\right.\\
&\left.+\int_{d}^{d+a} e^{i(2 \rho x+\pi)} d x+\int_{2 d}^{2 d+a} e^{i 2 \rho x} d x\right] \\
=& A_{0} e^{-i w t} e^{i \rho a} \frac{\sin (\rho a)}{\rho a}\left(1-e^{i 2 \rho d}+e^{i 4 \rho d}\right) e^{i 2 \rho d} \\
=& A_{0} e^{i(\beta+4 \gamma-w t)} \frac{\sin \beta}{\beta} \frac{\cos (3 \gamma)}{\cos \gamma},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\rho=\frac{\pi}{\lambda} \sin \theta, \beta=\rho a, \gamma=\rho d$. Thus

$$
I \sim\left(\frac{\sin \beta}{\beta}\right)^{2}\left[\frac{\cos (3 \gamma)}{\cos \gamma}\right]^{2} .
$$

The first diffraction minimum occurs at

$$
\beta=\pm \pi, \text { i.e., } \theta=\pm \sin ^{-1}\left(\frac{\lambda}{a}\right)
$$The first interference minimum occurs at

$$
3 \gamma=\pm \frac{\pi}{2} \text {, i.e., } \theta=\pm \sin ^{-1}\left(\frac{\lambda}{6 d}\right) \text {. }
$$

Problem Statement:
A Young double-slit interferometer receives light from a stellar object which is focused at the plane shown in the figure.

If the interferometer is pointed at a stellar object subtending, at the earth, an angle greater than $\theta_{\min}$, the pattern disappears. Find $\theta_{\min}$.
Solution:
Let the width of each slit be $a$ and the angular sise of the star be $\theta$. To good approximation the intensity distribution of the interference pattern is given by the result of Question 2007:

$$
I(x, \theta) \sim\left(\frac{\sin \beta}{\beta}\right)^{2}\left(1+\frac{\sin \alpha}{\alpha} \cos \gamma\right)
$$

where

$$
\beta=\frac{\pi a x}{\lambda f}, \alpha=\frac{\pi d \theta}{\lambda}, \gamma=\frac{2 \pi d x}{\lambda f} .
$$The visibility of the pattern is given by

$$
V=\frac{I_{\max }-I_{\min }}{I_{\max }+I_{\min }},
$$

where $I_{\max }$ and $I_{\min }$ are the intensities at the neighboring maximum and minimum respectively. Thus

$$
V=\frac{\sin \alpha}{\alpha} .
$$

As $\theta$ increases from 0 to $\theta_{\min }, V$ decreases from 1 to 0 , where $\theta_{\min }$ is given by

$$
\frac{\pi d \theta_{\min }}{\lambda}=\pi \text {, or } \theta_{\min }=\frac{\lambda}{d} .
$$

The pattern also appears when $\theta \geq \theta_{\min }$. Actually, beyond $\theta_{\min }$ the pattern may reappear and then disappear again many times but the fluctuation of $V$ around 0 becomes smaller and smaller.

Problem Statement:
A thin, positive lens $L_{1}$ forms a real image of an object located very far way, as shown in the first figure. The image is located at a distance $4 l$ and has height $h$. A negative lens $L_{2}$, of focal length $l$ is placed $2 l$ from $L_{1}$. A positive lens, of focal length $2 l$, is placed $3 l$ from $L_{1}$, as shown in the second figure.

Find the distance from $L_{1}$ of the resultant image.
Solution:
we have

Use the Gaussian lens formula $\frac{1}{u}+\frac{1}{v}=\frac{1}{f}$. Referring to Fig. $1.41$

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\mathrm{L}_{1}: v_{1}=4 l ; \\
&\mathrm{L}_{2}: f^{2}=-l, u_{2}=-(4-2) l=-2 l, \text { giving } v_{2}=-2 l ; \\
&\mathrm{L}_{3}: f_{3}=2 l, u_{3}=2 l+l=3 l \text {, giving } v_{3}=6 l .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, the distance from $\mathrm{L}_{1}$ of the resultant image is $3 l+6 l=9 l$.

Problem Statement:
A new and important experimental technique being used in several sub-fields of physics is the use of ultra-short light pulses for studying fast phenomena. The ultra-short pulses are produced by mode-locking a laser - a method to be studied in this problem. The model laser consists of an optical cavity of length $L$ with transverse dimensions $d$ formed by two flat mirrors as shown in the first figure.

The amplifying medium (it may be solid, liquid, or gas) can be characterized by a certain gain spectrum (see the second figure); only light within this band of frequencies will be amplified. To simplify calculation, assume the gain spectrum is rectangular as shown in the third figure.

To be specific, consider the amplifying medium Nd glass, which has $\omega_{0}=1.8 \times 10^{15} \mathrm{sec}^{-1}, \Delta \omega=6 \times 10^{12} \mathrm{sec}^{-1}$, and take the length of the laser to be $L=150 \mathrm{~cm}$.

The rectangular gain spectrum will result in each mode within the gain band having equal amplitude. If the intensity of an individual mode is $I_{0}$, what is the total intensity when the relative phases $\phi_{n}$ of the different modes are randomly distributed?
Solution:
The longitudinal modes that can exist in a cavity of length $L$ are those for which

$$
L=n \frac{\lambda}{2}, \quad(n=1,2,3, \ldots),
$$

i.e.,

$$
\omega_{L}=\frac{2 \pi c}{\lambda}=\frac{\pi n c}{L} .
$$

Hence the separation between adjacent modes is

$$
\delta \omega_{L}=\frac{\pi c}{L}=6.3 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~s}^{-1} .
$$If the relative phases $\phi_{n}$ of the different modes are randomly distributed, the modes are incoherent with one another, and the total intensity is the sum of the intensities of the individual modes; that is

$$
I=\text { integer }\left(\frac{\Delta \omega}{\delta \omega_{L}}\right) \cdot I_{0}=9549 I_{0} .
$$

Problem Statement:
A ray of light enters a spherical drop of water of index $n$ as shown in the figure.

Find the angle $\phi$ which produces minimum deflection.

$$
\left(\text { Hint : } \frac{d \sin ^{-1} x}{d x}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^{2}}}\right) \text {. }
$$
Solution:
(1) Figure $1.22$ shows the angles $\phi, \alpha, \phi-\alpha, x, \delta, \alpha$ is given by Snell's law $n \sin \alpha=\sin \phi$. Since $\sin \alpha=\frac{1}{n} \sin \phi<\frac{1}{n}$, i.e., the angle of incidence $\alpha$ is smaller than the critical angle $\sin ^{-1} \frac{1}{n}$, the incident light is reflected partially at the back spherical surface.

(2) As $\alpha=(\phi-\alpha)+x$, or $x=2 \alpha-\phi$, we have $\delta=\pi-2 x=\pi-4 \alpha+2 \phi$.

(3) For minimum deflection, we require $\frac{d \delta}{d \phi}=-4 \frac{d \alpha}{d \phi}+2=0$, or $\frac{d \alpha}{d \phi}=\frac{1}{2}$. As

$$
\alpha=\sin ^{-1}\left(\frac{1}{n} \sin \phi\right),
$$

we have $\frac{d \alpha}{d \phi}=\frac{1}{n} \frac{\cos \phi}{\cos \alpha}$ and the above gives

$$
1-\frac{1}{n^{2}} \sin ^{2} \phi=\frac{4}{n^{2}} \cos ^{2} \phi,
$$

or

$$
1=\frac{1}{n^{2}}+\frac{3}{n^{2}} \cos ^{2} \phi,
$$

giving

$$
\cos ^{2} \phi=\frac{n^{2}-1}{3} .
$$

Problem Statement:

as $\varphi=\frac{2 \pi d \sin \theta}{\lambda}$. The maximum intensity is given by $\frac{\delta}{2}=0$, so that $I_{m} \sim$ $4 N^{2}$. Hence

Problem Statement:
A two-slit diffraction system is illuminated normally with coherent light of wavelength $\lambda$. The separation between the slits is $a$. The intensity of light detected at a distant screen (far compared with $a$), when one of the slits is covered, is $I_{0}$.

For the situation where both slits are open, calculate the response of the detector as a function of the angle $\theta$, where $\theta$ is measured away from the normal to the system.
Solution:
Assume the widths of the slits are much smaller than $\lambda$, then one need not consider the diffraction produced by each slit. Only the interference between beams from different slits needs to be considered.

The amplitudes of the waves at a point on the screen produced individually by the slits are given by

$$
E_{1}=A e^{i k r_{1}}
$$

and

$$
E_{2}=A e^{i k r_{2}}=A e^{i k r_{1}} \cdot e^{i k a \sin \theta},
$$

where $k=\frac{2 \pi}{\lambda}, r_{1}$ and $r_{2}$ are the distances between the point and the two slits. The resultant intensity is

$$
\begin{aligned}
I \sim E E^{*} &=2 A^{2}[1+\cos (k a \sin \theta)] \\
&=4 A^{2} \cos ^{2}\left(\frac{\pi a \sin \theta}{\lambda}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

and is plotted in Fig. 2.24.

Problem Statement: A double-slit interference is produced by plane parallel light of wavelength $\lambda$ passing through two slits of unequal widths, say $w_{1}=20 \lambda$ and $w_{\Omega}=40 \lambda$, their centers being $1000 \lambda$ apart. If the observation is made on a screen very far away from the slits, i.e., at a distance $L \gg 1000 \lambda$, determine the width $\Delta x_{1}$ of the central maximum of the diffraction pattern of the first slit (i.e., distance between the first zeros).
Solution:
As $w_{2}=2 w_{1}, L>w_{1}, w_{2}$, we may take the amplitudes of the electric field vectors produced by the slits $S_{1}$ and $S_{2}$ individually on the screen to be $E$ and $2 E$ respectively. Since $I \propto E^{2}$, the corresponding intensities are $I_{1}=I_{0}$, say, $I_{2}=4 I_{0}$. For double-slit interference the resultant amplitude is given by the vector sum of $E_{1}$ and $E_{2}$ making an angle $\delta$ equal to the phase difference. Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
I &=I_{1}+I_{2}+2 \sqrt{I_{1} I_{2}} \cos \delta \\
&=I_{0}+4 I_{0}+4 I_{0} \cos (2 \pi d \sin \theta / \lambda)=5 I_{0}+4 I_{0} \cos (2000 \pi \sin \theta),
\end{aligned}
$$

where $d$ is the separation of the centres of the slits, being equal to $1000 \lambda$, $\sin \theta \approx \frac{x}{L}, x$ being the distance on the screen from the centre of the interference pattern. As $L>x, \sin \theta \simeq \theta$ and adjacent maxima occur when $2000 \pi \delta \theta=2 \pi$, or $\delta \theta=\frac{1}{1000}$, giving

$$
\delta x=L \delta \theta=\frac{L}{1000} .
$$The diffraction intensity distribution due to a slit of width $w$ is given by $\sim\left(\frac{\sin \beta}{\beta}\right)^{2}$, where $\beta=\frac{\pi w}{\lambda} \sin \theta$. Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
&I_{1}=I_{0}\left(\sin \beta_{1} / \beta_{1}\right)^{2}, \quad \text { where } \beta_{1}=\pi w_{1} \sin \theta / \lambda=20 \pi \sin \theta, \\
&I_{2}=4 I_{0}\left(\sin \beta_{2} / \beta_{2}\right)^{2}, \quad \text { where } \beta_{2}=\pi w_{2} \sin \theta / \lambda=40 \pi \sin \theta .
\end{aligned}
$$

The first zeros occur at angular distances from the centre of $\theta_{1}$ and $\theta_{2}$ given by

$$
20 \pi \sin \theta_{1} \simeq 20 \pi \theta_{1}=\pi \text {, or } \theta_{1}=\frac{1}{20} \text {, and } \theta_{2}=\frac{1}{40} \text {. }
$$

Hence the angular widths of the central maxima are

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta \theta_{1}=2 \theta_{1} &=\frac{1}{10}, \\
\Delta \theta_{2} &=\frac{1}{20} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The corresponding widths are then

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\Delta x_{1}=L \theta_{1}=L / 10, \\
&\Delta x_{2}=L \theta_{2}=L / 20 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Problem Statement:
A point source, $Q$, emits coherent light isotropically at two frequencies, $\omega$ and $\omega+\Delta \omega$, with equal power, $I$ joules/sec, at each frequency. Two detectors, $A$ and $B$, each with a (small) sensitive area $S$ capable of responding to individual photons, are located at distances $l_{A}$ and $l_{B}$ from $Q$ as shown in the figure. In the following, take $\frac{\Delta \omega}{\omega} \ll 1$ and assume the experiment is carried out in vacuum.

Calculate the photon counting rate (photons/sec) at $A$ as a function of time. Consider time scales $>1 / \omega$.
Solution:
The waves of angular frequencies $\omega_{1}$ and $\omega_{2}$ arriving at $A$ can be represented by

$$
\begin{aligned}
E_{1} &=\frac{E_{0}}{l_{A}} e^{i\left(\omega_{1} t-k_{2} l_{A}\right)} \\
E_{2} &=\frac{E_{0}}{l_{A}} e^{i\left(\omega_{2} t-k_{2} l_{A}\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

respectively, where $\omega_{1}=\omega, \omega_{2}=\omega+\Delta \omega$. The resultant wave at $A$ is then

$$
E_{\mathrm{A}}=E_{1}+E_{2}=\left(E_{0} / l_{\mathrm{A}}\right)\left[e^{i\left(\omega_{1} t-k_{1} l_{\mathrm{A}}\right)}+e^{i\left(\omega_{2} t-k_{2} l_{A}\right)}\right]
$$

and the intensity at $A$, time-averaged, is

$$
I_{\mathrm{A}} \sim \frac{1}{2} E_{\mathrm{A}} E_{\mathrm{A}}^{*}=\left(\frac{E_{0}}{l_{\mathrm{A}}}\right)^{2}\left\{1+\cos \left[\left(\omega_{2}-\omega_{1}\right) t-\left(k_{2}-k_{1}\right) l_{\mathrm{A}}\right]\right\} .
$$

The constant phase difference $\left(k_{2}-k_{1}\right) l_{A}$ can be taken as zero by choosing a suitable time origin. The intensity of the $\omega_{1}$ wave at $A$ is

As the source has power $I$ and is isotropic,

$$
I_{1} \sim \frac{1}{2} E_{1} E_{1}^{*}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{E_{0}}{l_{\mathrm{A}}}\right)^{2} .
$$

giving

$$
I_{1}=\frac{I}{4 \pi l_{A}^{2}},
$$

Hence

$$
\left(\frac{E_{0}}{l_{A}}\right)^{2} \sim \frac{I}{2 \pi l_{A}^{2}} .
$$

The photon counting rate at $A$ is

$$
I_{A}=\frac{I}{2 \pi l_{A}^{2}}[1+\cos (\Delta \omega t)] .
$$

Similarly, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
R_{\mathrm{A}}(t) &=\frac{I_{\mathrm{A}}(t) S}{\hbar \omega} . \\
&=\frac{I S}{2 \pi \hbar \omega l_{\mathrm{A}}^{2}}[1+\cos (\Delta \omega t)] .
\end{aligned}
$$

As

$$
I_{\mathrm{B}}(t)=\frac{I}{2 \pi l_{\mathrm{B}}^{2}}\left\{1+\cos \left[\Delta \omega t+\left(l_{\mathrm{B}}-l_{\mathrm{A}}\right)\left(k_{1}-k_{2}\right) \mid\right\} .\right.
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
&k_{1}=\frac{\omega_{1}}{c}=\frac{\omega}{c}, \\
&k_{2}=\frac{\omega_{2}}{c}=\frac{\omega+\Delta \omega}{c}, \\
&k_{1}-k_{2}=-\frac{\Delta \omega}{c},
\end{aligned}
$$

we have

$$
I_{B}(t)=\frac{I}{2 \pi l_{B}^{2}}\left\{1+\cos \left[\Delta \omega t+\frac{\left(l_{A}-l_{B}\right)}{c} \Delta \omega\right]\right\},
$$

giving

$$
R_{\mathrm{B}}(t)=\frac{I S}{2 \pi \hbar \omega l_{\mathrm{A}}^{2}}\left\{1+\cos \left[\Delta \omega t+\frac{\left(l_{\mathrm{A}}-l_{\mathrm{B}}\right) \Delta \omega}{c}\right]\right\} .
$$
